title: 114_hr3606
content: The Act titled "Child Trafficking Victims Protection Act" aims to protect child trafficking victims. The Act "Child Trafficking Victims Protection Act" defines "unaccompanied alien children" and mandates training for personnel who interact with them. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure proper care and transportation for these children during immigration proceedings. The Secretary of Homeland Security must transfer unaccompanied alien children to the Director of the Office of Refugee Resettlement within 72 hours, with emergency funds available in exceptional circumstances. Female officers should be present during the transfer of female detainees. The Secretary must provide trained staff and resources, including child welfare professionals. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure child welfare professionals are present at U.S. Customs and Border Protection ports of entry and stations for children in custody. Professionals must be hired based on the number of children in custody and be licensed in social work. Child welfare professionals at ports of entry and stations must be qualified, licensed in social work, and proficient in common languages spoken by apprehended children. They are responsible for developing treatment guidelines and reporting abuse allegations to appropriate authorities. The child welfare professionals at ports of entry and stations must report abuse allegations to the appropriate State and Federal child protection authorities. The Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection and the Director of the Office of Refugee Resettlement must ensure children can report abuse and misconduct and comply with child abuse reporting laws. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection Internal Affairs Office, Office of Refugee Resettlement, and area government subcontracted legal service providers must be notified of child abuse allegations. Screening of unaccompanied alien children must be conducted in accordance with the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection must notify relevant authorities of child abuse allegations and conduct screenings of unaccompanied alien children according to the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008. Recommendations for placement of accompanied children and families should be provided to the Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs. The Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement must interview adult relatives accompanying unaccompanied alien children, provide family relationship and trafficking assessments, and ensure the best interests of the child are considered for release. The Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement must ensure that children in custody receive necessary medical and mental health care, appropriate clothing, and basic hygiene products. Children in custody must have access to sanitary products, bedding, nutrition, a safe living environment, recreational activities, legal services, consular officials, and supervised phone calls to family members. Procedures should be developed to prioritize the child's best interests in migration deterrence. The interests of the child in migration deterrence programs at a border include determining if the child is with a parent or legal guardian, assessing any humanitarian concerns or safety issues for the apprehended parent or guardian, and ensuring decisions consider the best interests of the individual. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consider the best interests of the apprehended individual's child, family unity, and other public interest factors. They should also coordinate with the Mexican Consulate for the safe repatriation of Mexican children. Additionally, procedures for human rights monitoring by nongovernmental organizations will be developed. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report on screening procedures for unaccompanied alien children and assess their effectiveness annually. Immediate notification to the Office of Refugee Resettlement is required for unaccompanied alien children in custody within 48 hours. The Secretary of Homeland Security must ensure timely coordination for the transfer and placement of unaccompanied children with the Office of Refugee Resettlement. Children must receive interviews, screenings, and information on their rights under the Immigration and Nationality Act, including access to counsel. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must maintain privacy and confidentiality of information related to care, custody, and services for unaccompanied alien children. The Secretary must also ensure that video orientations are available in English and the 5 most common native languages spoken by children in custody. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must maintain privacy and confidentiality of information related to care for unaccompanied alien children, only disclosing information in writing if in the child's best interest or authorized by the child or approved sponsor. Additionally, fundamental child protection policies and procedures must be adopted. Fundamental child protection policies and procedures must be developed, including reliable age determinations without using forensic testing, deferring removal if a child faces life-threatening harm, and ensuring physical separation of unaccompanied alien children from adults and other detainees. The Repatriation and Reintegration Program aims to support the safe return and integration of unaccompanied alien children with the help of various government and non-governmental organizations. The Repatriation and Reintegration Program supports the safe return and integration of unaccompanied alien children by identifying their needs, partnering with community organizations, involving the family, and providing a variety of services like access to education and skills training. The Repatriation and Reintegration Program includes procedures for safe repatriation of unaccompanied alien children, addressing special needs of girls, tender-aged children, and vulnerable children. The Administrator of the Agency for International Development must submit a report on repatriation and reintegration within 18 months of the Act's enactment and annually thereafter. The Secretary of Homeland Security shall transfer funds to the Department of Health and Human Services for repatriation and reintegration programs for unaccompanied alien children. A report must be submitted before any proposed actions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must submit a detailed expenditure plan 15 days before any proposed transfer of funds for repatriation and reintegration programs for unaccompanied alien children to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations.
